content: As the thread title says, I was very disappointed to see so few homes flying their flags flying on this Memorial Day. Living with my mom, just the two of us, I climbed up the long ladder, slipped the flag into the holder screwed high up on the second deck of her house, and turned around to see that it was the only flag on the street. Later, the neighbor next door (retired Marine) put up his flag, and then another one went up (retired Navy). In all, only three flags were flying in honor of Memorial Day ... on a residential street of 25 houses. Today, here at work, I mentioned this to three of my active duty Navy colleagues, and we all agreed that flag sightings were indeed rare this weekend. Very disappointing. Is this a trend?? If so, why??
reply: As the thread title says, I was very disappointed to see so few homes flying their flags flying on this Memorial Day. If so, why??
title: Memorial Day -- where were the flags?

content: Must have been a (lack of) trend in your area. Around here, Scout Troops "sell" large flags on 8 foot standards, which they keep and store - but every major Holiday, they come around and plant the Flags on the front lawns of the people thar have paid the $25.00 - For Ever, I guess. I bought mine and keep it here, so I can plant it out there whenever and for as long as I wish. I put mine up Friday afternoon and just took it down an hour or so ago... They also had similar Flags posted all over our Cemeteries, and I do have some pictures of that yesterday and this morning: These are all done as Scout Troop fund raisers and Eagle Scout Projects - - Get the local Scouts involved-ahey!! Wandering and Wondering

title: Memorial Day -- where were the flags?

content: I picked one up from the ditch. I'm sure someone was displaying his "patriotic spirit" by flying it on his vehicle. But he/she didn't have enough "patriotic spirit" to bother picking it up when it broke off the car. My husband and I were on the way to town when I saw it and told him. He immediately stopped and backed up so we could "rescue" it. My husband, by the way, was born in another country. I'd be willing to bet the previous owner of that flag was a "red-blooded American".
reply: I picked one up from the ditch. I'm sure someone was displaying his "patriotic spirit" by flying it on his vehicle. title: Memorial Day -- where were the flags?

content: Not everyone flys the flag. A lot of people who are not connected to the military in any way have no idea what this day really means. My dad 26 years of AF, does not fly one. We fly one with a Marine flag. But when the weather beats it all to hell, we wait a while before flying another one. My inlaws don't fly one. We don't fly one on our cars. I don't put anything on my cars except for USMC Retired in the back window and a border around the plates. And it is actually against the law to put anything around the plates. But I don't think a cop will screw with us on that. I think the person who lost their flag was on elderly person and didn't want to get out of the car to get it. I would not expect for my dad, 88 to get out of his car if his flag came off of his car.

I would not expect for my dad, 88 to get out of his car if his flag came off of his car.

content: Had not displayed our flag for a while, trying to keep it in shape and out of bad weather. Put it up when the rain stopped about the time the President completed his memorial day speech. Got the BBQ pit in the front yard near the flag pole. Thought about those lives lost for our sake the whole time. In the rain, cooked up a good supper for two sons who are in the process of re-enlisting. One came back from meeting with the recruiter just in time to eat.

title: Memorial Day -- where were the flags?

content: I stopped flying a flag at my house all year long. The wind blows from the west an wraps it around an over the pole. What is worse than not flying the flag, is flying a flag that is torn an ragged & tatterd. I use to drive around town and leave a note in their mail box about their flags condition.
reply: I stopped flying a flag at my house all year long. The wind blows from the west an wraps it around an over the pole. What is worse than not flying the flag, is flying a flag that is torn an ragged & tatterd. I use to drive around town and leave a note in their mail box about their flags condition.
title: Memorial Day -- where were the flags?

content: Yankeee ~ my new flag has a “no wrap hem” works 95% of the time. . . Last year I had extra flags leftover from the Memorial Park. The night before Memorial Day I walked the neighborhood and put a flag at the end of everyone’s driveway. All but about four had the same flags back out this year. now 11 September is a day you see less and less American flags flying. . . choose joy each day

title: Memorial Day -- where were the flags?

content: Not sure where you are at 1WW, but I think there were more flags flying in town than there are people here. Mind you my little corner of the woods is a bit backwards according to some folks, in some ways it is still the 1950's here. We have around 1,000 people in the entire town, there was a flag at all but 7 houses, one at the city hall/fire department/police office(New building too, we finished it a few years back). The City cafe has a display they keep out from 6 am to 6 pm every day of all the armed forces flags and the national flag... Maybe it is part of being in a small town were almost every single male has served, but here on memorial day flags you will find, people are another matter, we usually end up in the back yard around the grill with some ribs, burgers, dogs, and suds. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

content: My flag flies 24/7 with a spot light at night. I do agree there seems to be a lack of flag flying in my neighborhood. VETERANS....The Greatest Fraternity!

content: +1 On the proper occasions it is lowered smartly to half-staff for the prescribed time. When it becomes unservicable it is retired with honors. A flag every year or so isn't going to break the bank. A bare flagpole breaks your heart and spirit.

content: I fly the flag all day and night too. Mine iws lit up at night also. Our town has flags flying on Memorial day and at the cementaries also on Memorial day. The VFW and American Legion posts put them up. Plus there are many homes around here that fly the flag. We are a patriotic town here.
reply: I fly the flag all day and night too. Mine iws lit up at night also. Our town has flags flying on Memorial day and at the cementaries also on Memorial day. The VFW and American Legion posts put them up. Plus there are many homes around here that fly the flag. We are a patriotic town here.

content: 1WW, sorry to hear about the lack of flags in your area. Here in NH, they were all over as far as public areas though I too, would have liked to see some more on the homes of folks here. I did get to enjoy putting one up in front of my next door neighbor's apartment. He is a Vietnam Vet stuck in a wheelchair because of exposure to Agent Orange. Don

title: Memorial Day -- where were the flags?

content: I am amazed here in Washington State. AS LIBERAL as this state is, the residents KNOW whre that freedom comes from. they honor the military, the veterans and the sacrifices. this state, unlike Texas, has parades, cermonies, festivities with full pomp. we ay be a little on the left, but the right thing is done for this nation. there were flags everywhere, and at the grave yard there were people waiting to get in. Veterans wore their medals and kids were educated in why they live in a house and not in a pile of rubble.
reply: I am amazed here in Washington State. content: The town I live in, Raymond, NH, celebrates Memorial Day this coming Saturday, May 30th. I'm told it's the traditional date rather than a convienant three day weekend for the public. Not sure what all that's about but it works for me. The weather is suppose to be sunny if the forecasts hold up. Raymond Traditional Memorial Day RAYMOND – The veterans of Foreign Wars and the American Legion will observe Memorial Day on Sat., May 30 “the traditional Memorial Day”. A parade will convene at 10:00 a.m. on Upper Main Street and then proceed to the Pine Grove Cemetery and the Veterans Cemetery on …pping Street, where services will be performed. Then return to the Common for a final service. Music will be conducted by the Raymond School Band. link: carriagetownenews.com/local/local_story_134101233.html Don

title: Memorial Day -- where were the flags?

content: I just moved into a new house, and we don't even have a lawn, much less a flagpole. It's in the plans, though. I have to say, however, that I'd rather see one well-displayed flag than 20 poorly displayed flags. In my previous neighborhood, there was a guy who had this mid-sized flag stuck on a small pole in his front yard. It flew day and night without a light, and it was faded, torn, and tattered. He finally took it down, but it angered me every time I saw it. What's worse is that the guy probably got some false sense of patriotism out of abusing the flag like that. But as for this weekend, I wasn't home anyway. I was at an event at Crown Center in Kansas City. On Sunday night, everyone who was still left from the event watched the fireworks and listened to the orchestra together. It was brilliant, right over the big memorial on the hill. So, maybe I didn't fly a flag, but I didn't forget. Isn't that what memorial day is about?

content: For an anniversary present, my Mother In Law bought me a flag and pole for our house. She's not a big fan of the military, but I thought it was an awesome gesture on her part. We've been flying our flag now for just under 2 months and I LOVE it! And it's one of the ones that sits in a holder on the porch post so we get to take it with us when we move. I know the feeling of "where are the flags?"... We have 4 on our street, and sadly the numbers are dwindling in our neighboring streets...
reply: For an anniversary present, my Mother In Law bought me a flag and pole for our house. She's not a big fan of the military, but I thought it was an awesome gesture on her part. content: I posted this picture before, but it belongs here to some degree. Remember, cost is not a problem for someone who wants to fly a flag. 20' piece of metal pipe, from out in the garage, no charge. White enamel paint from ace hardware, $10 5' piece of PVC pipe, from the garage no charge. Rope, I keep the stuff by the mile, no charge. Pulleys and snap hooks from ace, a few bucks. Flags, cost varies with size and type, and is not that bad. American flag, 4 foot hoise, all weather poly. $20 Old navy jack, gift from my chief when I was discharged. Alabama state flag, $7 POW/MIA flag, $7 A damned fine setup for some $50, acccumulated a little at the time, from just the pole and American flag, to the addition of the crossbar and axtra flags. The ball on top was from the schools old flag pole, a little gold paint and it looked like new. Can't even see the dent in the side of it. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

content: As the thread title says, I was very disappointed to see so few homes flying their flags flying on this Memorial Day. Living with my mom, just the two of us, I climbed up the long ladder, slipped the flag into the holder screwed high up on the second deck of her house, and turned around to see that it was the only flag on the street. Later, the neighbor next door (retired Marine) put up his flag, and then another one went up (retired Navy). In all, only three flags were flying in honor of Memorial Day ... on a residential street of 25 houses. Today, here at work, I mentioned this to three of my active duty Navy colleagues, and we all agreed that flag sightings were indeed rare this weekend. Very disappointing. Is this a trend?? If so, why??

Mind you my little corner of the woods is a bit backwards according to some folks, in some ways it is still the 1950's here. We have around 1,000 people in the entire town, there was a flag at all but 7 houses, one at the city hall/fire department/police office(New building too, we finished it a few years back). The City cafe has a display they keep out from 6 am to 6 pm every day of all the armed forces flags and the national flag... Maybe it is part of being in a small town were almost every single male has served, but here on memorial day flags you will find, people are another matter, we usually end up in the back yard around the grill with some ribs, burgers, dogs, and suds. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.
reply: Not sure where you are at 1WW, but I think there were more flags flying in town than there are people here. Mind you my little corner of the woods is a bit backwards according to some folks, in some ways it is still the 1950's here. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

content: +1 On the proper occasions it is lowered smartly to half-staff for the prescribed time. When it becomes unservicable it is retired with honors. A flag every year or so isn't going to break the bank. A bare flagpole breaks your heart and spirit.

content: I fly the flag all day and night too. Mine iws lit up at night also. Our town has flags flying on Memorial day and at the cementaries also on Memorial day. The VFW and American Legion posts put them up. Plus there are many homes around here that fly the flag. We are a patriotic town here.

content: 1WW, sorry to hear about the lack of flags in your area. Here in NH, they were all over as far as public areas though I too, would have liked to see some more on the homes of folks here. I did get to enjoy putting one up in front of my next door neighbor's apartment. He is a Vietnam Vet stuck in a wheelchair because of exposure to Agent Orange. Don

content: I am amazed here in Washington State. AS LIBERAL as this state is, the residents KNOW whre that freedom comes from. they honor the military, the veterans and the sacrifices. this state, unlike Texas, has parades, cermonies, festivities with full pomp. we ay be a little on the left, but the right thing is done for this nation. there were flags everywhere, and at the grave yard there were people waiting to get in. Veterans wore their medals and kids were educated in why they live in a house and not in a pile of rubble.
reply: I am amazed here in Washington State. content: The town I live in, Raymond, NH, celebrates Memorial Day this coming Saturday, May 30th. I'm told it's the traditional date rather than a convienant three day weekend for the public. Not sure what all that's about but it works for me. The weather is suppose to be sunny if the forecasts hold up. Raymond Traditional Memorial Day RAYMOND – The veterans of Foreign Wars and the American Legion will observe Memorial Day on Sat., May 30 “the traditional Memorial Day”. A parade will convene at 10:00 a.m. on Upper Main Street and then proceed to the Pine Grove Cemetery and the Veterans Cemetery on …pping Street, where services will be performed. Then return to the Common for a final service. Music will be conducted by the Raymond School Band. link: carriagetownenews.com/local/local_story_134101233.html Don

title: Memorial Day -- where were the flags?

content: I just moved into a new house, and we don't even have a lawn, much less a flagpole. It's in the plans, though. I have to say, however, that I'd rather see one well-displayed flag than 20 poorly displayed flags. In my previous neighborhood, there was a guy who had this mid-sized flag stuck on a small pole in his front yard. It flew day and night without a light, and it was faded, torn, and tattered. He finally took it down, but it angered me every time I saw it. What's worse is that the guy probably got some false sense of patriotism out of abusing the flag like that. But as for this weekend, I wasn't home anyway. I was at an event at Crown Center in Kansas City. On Sunday night, everyone who was still left from the event watched the fireworks and listened to the orchestra together. It was brilliant, right over the big memorial on the hill. So, maybe I didn't fly a flag, but I didn't forget. Isn't that what memorial day is about?

content: For an anniversary present, my Mother In Law bought me a flag and pole for our house. She's not a big fan of the military, but I thought it was an awesome gesture on her part. We've been flying our flag now for just under 2 months and I LOVE it! And it's one of the ones that sits in a holder on the porch post so we get to take it with us when we move. I know the feeling of "where are the flags?"... We have 4 on our street, and sadly the numbers are dwindling in our neighboring streets...

content: I posted this picture before, but it belongs here to some degree. Remember, cost is not a problem for someone who wants to fly a flag. 20' piece of metal pipe, from out in the garage, no charge. White enamel paint from ace hardware, $10 5' piece of PVC pipe, from the garage no charge. Rope, I keep the stuff by the mile, no charge. Pulleys and snap hooks from ace, a few bucks. Flags, cost varies with size and type, and is not that bad. American flag, 4 foot hoise, all weather poly. $20 Old navy jack, gift from my chief when I was discharged. Alabama state flag, $7 POW/MIA flag, $7 A damned fine setup for some $50, acccumulated a little at the time, from just the pole and American flag, to the addition of the crossbar and axtra flags. The ball on top was from the schools old flag pole, a little gold paint and it looked like new. Can't even see the dent in the side of it. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.
